description: Orthographic borrowing from French kaolin, from the Wade–Giles romanization of Mandarin 高嶺／高岭 (Gāolǐng, “high hill”), in Jingdezhen, Jiangxi province, China, the location where this clay was first found.

entries.meaning: A fine clay, rich in kaolinite, used in ceramics, paper-making, etc.
examples: Grind with strong arm, the circling chertz betwixt, / Your pure Ka-o-lins and Pe-tun-tses mixt  […] .
